payPowerReports.label: Pay Power Potential: Weak
payPowerReports.description: Your negotiating leverage is currently constrained. This does not mean you're underperforming or underpaid—it means the balance of power in the market isn't strongly in your favor right now.
recommendedActions: Avoid high-stakes negotiation or risky moves
Focus on building leverage before making a change
Invest in skills, role expansion, or market repositioning
Treat this as a setup phase, not a verdict

payPowerReports.label: Pay Power Potential: Moderate
payPowerReports.description: You have some leverage, but it's uneven. Certain factors are working in your favor, while others may limit your ability to negotiate or move freely right now.
recommendedActions: Be intentional about when and how you negotiate
Strengthen areas that limit leverage (skills, visibility, scope)
Use data and timing to guide decisions

payPowerReports.label: Pay Power Potential: Strong
payPowerReports.description: You're operating from a position of real leverage. Your skills, experience, and market positioning give you options—whether that's negotiating, exploring opportunities, or being selective about your next move.
recommendedActions: Consider negotiating compensation, scope, or role level
Be selective—avoid lateral or low-impact moves
Pressure-test market value before accepting offers
Focus on strategic, not reactive, decisions

freeReport.globalDisclaimer: The Pay Power Score measures leverage, not worth. It reflects your position in the market at a point in time, and it can change.

paidReportBreakdown.title: Detailed Pay Power Breakdown
paidReportBreakdown.description: This section provides deeper context and strategy behind your Pay Power Score. It is designed to help you understand not just where you stand, but what actually moves the score.

tiers.label: Pay Power Potential: Weak
tiers.whatThisMeans: Your negotiating leverage is currently constrained. This isn't a reflection of your ability or effort—it's a signal that the market does not yet have a strong business case to move aggressively on your behalf. At this level, pushing harder rarely works. Leverage isn't about asking—it's about signal.
whatThisTypicallyLooksLike: Compensation conversations framed around budgets, timing, or policy
Positive feedback without corresponding comp movement
Promotions discussed, then delayed or quietly deprioritized
Negotiations that stall or go nowhere
tiers.theCommonMistake: Trying to negotiate anyway. When leverage is weak, negotiation attempts can actually lower credibility and reinforce the perception that you're misreading your position.
tiers.theRealChallenge: Staying in this zone too long can flatten your long-term earnings trajectory. Small delays compound. Missed resets become harder to reclaim later. This isn't urgent because you're failing—it's urgent because timing matters.
whatActuallyMovesTheScore: Focus on market signal, not internal validation
Build proof of impact, scope expansion, or role/title alignment
Increase external optionality before re-entering conversations
Leverage is built before the conversation, not during it
tiers.strategicNextStep: Your priority is leverage-building, not negotiation. A targeted strategy can shorten this phase dramatically by focusing only on the highest-impact moves.

tiers.label: Pay Power Potential: Moderate
tiers.whatThisMeans: You have leverage, but it's uneven. Some factors are working in your favor, while others limit how far you can push. Outcomes here depend heavily on timing, framing, and restraint.
whatThisTypicallyLooksLike: Negotiations that succeed sometimes but not consistently
Relief after negotiations instead of confidence
tiers.theCommonMistake: Confusing fairness with optimality. Employers expect negotiation at this level. Under-anchoring signals uncertainty, not cooperation.
tiers.theRealChallenge: Small under-anchors compound quietly. A modest concession today can turn into six-figure losses over time. This is the most leverage-sensitive zone—smart moves accelerate you, sloppy ones stall you.
whatActuallyMovesTheScore: Use total compensation framing, not just salary
Sequence conversations so you never reveal your floor first
Strengthen the weakest pillar holding your score back
tiers.strategicNextStep: Your goal is to convert partial leverage into consistent wins. With the right structure, this is often the fastest tier to move up from.

tiers.label: Pay Power Potential: Strong
tiers.whatThisMeans: You're operating from a position of real leverage. Employers expect you to negotiate. Recruiters build flexibility into offers. The question is no longer whether you have power—it's how cleanly you deploy it.
whatThisTypicallyLooksLike: Negotiations that feel controlled, not tense
Influence over role scope, equity, or timing
tiers.theCommonMistake: Pushing harder instead of playing smarter. At this level, brute-force negotiation can cap upside, damage relationships, or cost long-term optionality.
tiers.theRealChallenge: Misplaying leverage. The biggest losses here aren't salary—they're equity structure, scope, influence, and future positioning. These mistakes don't show up immediately, but they compound massively.
whatActuallyMovesTheScore: Mastery of equity vs. cash tradeoffs
Thinking in portfolios, not single offers
Power here is less about force and more about architecture
tiers.strategicNextStep: Your leverage is real. The art is deploying it without overplaying your hand. Precision architecture beats pressure.
